results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings; it only states the review's purpose to summarize existing evidence.
population_specificity: Pregnant individuals who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the degree of obesity affects outcomes in morbidly obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery, comparing different procedures (LAGB, LSG, LRYGB).
results_summary: The study found that LRYGB provided the best mid-term results for weight loss and resolution of obesity-related comorbidities in super-obese patients, without significantly increased complications compared to LAGB and LSG.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients (BMI 40-49.9 kg/m²) undergoing bariatric surgery (75% women).
study_duration: At least two years of follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immunological and metabolic adaptations resulting from bariatric surgery, focusing on its effects on chronic inflammation and immune cell phenotypes in severe obesity.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery leads to significant weight loss, improved glucose metabolism, reduced systemic inflammation, and a shift in immune cell populations from proinflammatory to anti-inflammatory phenotypes, along with decreased oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term safety and effectiveness of bariatric surgery in individuals with Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS).
results_summary: The abstract states that the long-term safety and effectiveness of bariatric surgery in PWS remains unknown, indicating no conclusive findings were presented. Current standard treatments for PWS, including dietary modifications and growth hormone replacement, have limited efficacy for appetite and weight control.
population_specificity: Individuals with Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) experiencing excess weight gain and severe hyperphagia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether bariatric surgery could be a more effective intervention for optimizing outcomes in youth with type 2 diabetes compared to lifestyle interventions.
results_summary: The study suggested that optimizing outcomes in youth with T2D might require more robust interventions beyond family-level lifestyle changes, including bariatric surgery, but did not provide specific efficacy data on bariatric surgery itself.
population_specificity: Adolescents with type 2 diabetes (participants from the TODAY study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and metabolic effects of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) and one-anastomosis gastric bypass (OAGB) in bariatric patients through a prospective randomized controlled study.
results_summary: At the interim analysis (3 months), there were no deaths or ICU admissions, with one patient in each group requiring additional gastroscopy (anastomosis dilatation in RYGB, no intervention in OAGB). The trial was deemed safe to continue.
population_specificity: 120 bariatric patients from two academic centers, with 80 undergoing metabolic analyses at Helsinki University Hospital.
study_duration: Planned follow-up of 10 years, with interim analysis at 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the quality of online patient information related to bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that online patient information on bariatric surgery was of poor quality, with readability higher than recommended and no sources meeting the minimum recommended quality standards despite some accreditation.
population_specificity: Online healthcare information sources (websites) related to bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of bariatric surgery on food selection, nutrient status, eating behavior traits, and disordered eating behavior to understand their influence on weight loss success and trajectories.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery leads to significant weight loss initially (1-2 years post-surgery) due to reduced energy intake, higher dietary adherence, lower appetite, and improved wellbeing, but patients become susceptible to weight regain afterward, requiring cognitive effort and continued psychological and nutritional support.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing bariatric surgery (specific demographics not detailed).
study_duration: Up to 1-2 years post-surgery (with long-term follow-up implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of gut microbiota in type 2 diabetes and assess the potential of bariatric surgery as a treatment for gut microbiota dysbiosis.
results_summary: The study suggests that gut microbiota dysbiosis is linked to type 2 diabetes and highlights bariatric surgery as a potential intervention to restore microbiota balance, alongside other methods like fecal microbiota transplantation, prebiotics, and probiotics.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients with gut microbiota dysbiosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term weight loss efficacy of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy in obese patients over at least five years.
results_summary: The study found that gastric bypass resulted in greater weight loss than sleeve gastrectomy across all evaluated studies, though three of the seven included studies showed no statistically significant difference.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-65 years with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the overall and procedure-specific risks of bariatric surgery in patients with a history of cardiovascular disease (CVD).
results_summary: Patients with prior cardiac history (MI, PCI, or cardiac surgery) had significantly increased risks of perioperative cardiac arrest, 30-day mortality, and readmission. Sleeve gastrectomy (SG) was associated with fewer adverse events compared to Roux-En-Y gastric bypass (RYGB).
population_specificity: Patients with a history of MI, PCI, or cardiac surgery who underwent primary laparoscopic, laparoscopic-assisted, or robotic-assisted RYGB or SG.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the incidence and severity of bile reflux after one anastomosis gastric bypass (OAGB) using bile reflux scintigraphy (BRS) and endoscopy.
results_summary: The study found that 31.6% of patients had bile reflux in the gastric pouch, with 2.6% also experiencing reflux in the esophagus. Postoperative endoscopy revealed de novo bile reflux-related findings in 39.5% of patients, and reflux symptoms were significantly associated with BRS and endoscopic findings.
population_specificity: 40 patients (29 women) who underwent OAGB between November 2016 and December 2018.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of metabolic and bariatric surgery versus medical treatment for managing obesity and diabetes, including remission rates and complications.
results_summary: The study found that metabolic and bariatric surgery leads to significantly higher remission rates from type 2 diabetes, lower rates of macrovascular and microvascular complications, and reduced mortality compared to medical treatment. It also highlighted the potential benefits of earlier and more aggressive surgical intervention for obese or overweight individuals with diabetes.
population_specificity: Obese adults and adolescents with type 2 diabetes, and potentially obese individuals with type 1 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the risk of reintervention after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) versus vertical sleeve gastrectomy (VSG) in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: Patients undergoing VSG were less likely to require subsequent abdominal operative interventions compared to RYGB, except for bariatric conversion or revision procedures. VSG also showed lower risks for biliary procedures, abdominal wall hernia repair, other abdominal operations, endoscopy, and enteral access.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-64 with commercial insurance in the US who underwent RYGB or VSG between 2010-2017, matched by region, surgery year, BMI category, and baseline type 2 diabetes.
study_duration: Follow-up ranged up to 4 years (median 1.6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bariatric surgery could ameliorate atrial fibrillation (AF) and reduce the risk for heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) in patients with obesity or diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery can ameliorate AF and reduce the risk for HFpEF in patients with obesity or diabetes, potentially improving outcomes compared to other treatments like antihyperglycemic drugs or catheter ablation.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity or type 2 diabetes who have atrial fibrillation (AF) or are at risk for heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review treatment options for NAFLD, including bariatric surgery, focusing on weight loss and improvement of insulin resistance.
results_summary: The study highlights bariatric surgery as a key treatment for NAFLD, emphasizing its role in weight loss and insulin resistance improvement, though specific outcomes are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with NAFLD, particularly those with metabolic syndrome, weight gain, and insulin resistance/diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of doxapram on recovery outcomes following general anesthesia in morbidly obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Doxapram significantly reduced time to extubation, recovery time, and respiratory complications while improving vital signs and peak expiratory flow rate, with no reported complications.
population_specificity: 100 morbidly obese patients (69 women) with at least class two obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.
effective_dosage: Single dose of doxapram 1 mg/kg ideal body weight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent literature on surgical approaches, bariatric surgery, and therapeutic updates for treating endometrial cancer in obese patients.
results_summary: The study summarizes recent findings on bariatric surgery and endometrial cancer, including updates in radiation, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy for obese populations, but does not provide specific outcomes or data.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients with endometrial cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the clinical presentation, diagnostic procedures, and treatment of surgical complications of bariatric surgery during pregnancies.
results_summary: The study found that surgical complications of bariatric surgery during pregnancy, such as internal hernia and gastric banding slippage, can lead to severe outcomes, including maternal and fetal death (2.5% and 7.5%, respectively). Prompt diagnosis and multidisciplinary expertise are critical for managing these complications.
population_specificity: Women of childbearing age with a history of bariatric surgery who underwent emergency surgery during pregnancy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate a clinical prediction rule for the success of endoscopic stenting in managing anastomotic leaks after bariatric and cancer surgeries.
results_summary: The study found that the predictive model had good discriminative power (AUC 0.705), with a 72.5% positive predictive value for success when the predicted chance was >50%. Clinical success was achieved in 62% of patients.
population_specificity: Patients with anastomotic leaks after cancer (n=47) and bariatric surgery (n=6, inferred from total n=53).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare dental wear and tooth loss in eutrophic, morbidly obese, and post-bariatric surgery patients who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
results_summary: The study found that individuals who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass had more dental wear on incisal/occlusal surfaces, particularly in anterior teeth, regardless of surgery duration. Dental wear was associated with age and number of missing teeth.
population_specificity: 240 patients divided into four groups: eutrophic (60), morbidly obese (60), post-surgery ≤24 months (60), and post-surgery ≥36 months (60).
study_duration: Follow-up periods of up to 24 months and more than 36 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze innovative, minimally invasive bariatric surgery procedures as alternatives to classic laparoscopic methods, focusing on their development, clinical evidence, and future potential.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery is highly effective for morbid obesity, with low complication rates and significant improvements in quality of life. It reviews promising new techniques and devices, emphasizing their potential to reduce patient discomfort and enhance outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: To evaluate the relationship between obesity and urinary incontinence (UI) and determine the effect of weight reduction, particularly through bariatric surgery, on UI severity.
results_summary: Obesity is strongly associated with increased prevalence of stress and urgency UI. Weight reduction, especially via bariatric surgery, improves incontinence symptoms, with the degree of weight loss positively correlated with symptom improvement.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity and urinary incontinence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of bariatric surgery on migraine headaches through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly reduced migraine frequency and headache-related disability, with borderline significant reduction in severity. The study was limited by a small number of included studies.
population_specificity: Patients of all ages with a history of migraines undergoing primary bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effects of bariatric surgery on macrovascular complications and metabolic outcomes in severely obese patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly reduced the incidence of macrovascular complications, cardiovascular events, and myocardial infarction compared to conventional medical therapy. It also led to better weight loss and glycemic control over the long term.
population_specificity: Severely obese patients with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of bariatric surgery on type 2 diabetes remission and glucose outcomes between Asian and non-Asian populations over different follow-up periods.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery showed higher diabetes remission rates and greater reductions in HbA1c and fasting plasma glucose in Asian populations compared to non-Asian populations, with effects sustained over long-term follow-up (up to 5 years).
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes, comparing Asian and non-Asian populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the impact of bariatric surgery on diabetes mellitus by examining its history, clinical data, mechanisms of action, and future potential.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery induced diabetes remission in 33-90% of individuals at 1-year post-treatment, compared to 0-39% with medical management. The effects were attributed to weight-dependent and weight-independent mechanisms, including changes in intestinal physiology, hormone secretion, and microbiome.
population_specificity: Individuals with diabetes mellitus undergoing bariatric surgery or medical management.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess changes in post-occlusive reactive hyperemic response in skin microcirculation among extremely obese patients with and without hypertension after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Six months after bariatric surgery, improvements were observed in microvascular function, including shortened time to peak flows and increased hyperemia area, particularly in patients with hypertension. Variations in anthropometric, metabolic, and adipokine levels influenced these improvements.
population_specificity: Extremely obese patients (mean age 42.1 ± 11.2 years, 40.5% men) with and without hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (SG) and gastric bypass (GB) on depression scores (BDI) and weight reduction in obese patients.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery improved weight reduction and BDI scores regardless of the procedure type (SG or GB). Further studies with longer follow-up and larger samples are needed to clarify differences between the procedures.
population_specificity: 685 obese patients (84.8% female, mean age 38.7 ± 10.9, mean BMI 45.1 ± 6.0 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes of the novel SASJ bypass technique with other established bariatric surgery techniques over a 6-month follow-up period.
results_summary: All four bariatric surgery groups showed significant weight loss over 6 months, with no statistical differences in excess weight loss, BMI, hemoglobin A1C, or albumin levels. The SASJ bypass group achieved comparable weight loss (34.2 ± 5.4%) to the other techniques.
population_specificity: 100 patients with morbid obesity, divided into four groups of 25 each, undergoing different bariatric surgery techniques.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a specialized multivitamin supplement (WLS Optimum) compared to a standard multivitamin supplement (sMVS) in preventing vitamin and mineral deficiencies after laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy.
results_summary: The specialized supplement improved serum levels of folic acid and vitamin B1, reduced PTH levels, and lowered anemia rates compared to the standard supplement, but no differences were found for iron, vitamin B12, vitamin D, and other nutrients.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (n=139).
effective_dosage: WLS Optimum contained elevated doses of vitamins and minerals; sMVS provided 100% of the recommended dietary allowance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess Chinese nurses' knowledge of obesity and metabolic disorders and their attitudes toward bariatric surgery to improve their capability in this field.
results_summary: Nurses had high knowledge of obesity-related cardiovascular diseases and type 2 diabetes but lacked understanding of its links to carcinoma, gastroesophageal reflux, and psychological disorders. Acceptance of bariatric surgery's safety and efficacy was low, with concerns about postoperative complications.
population_specificity: Chinese nurses from multiple hospitals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the mid- and long-term weight loss, comorbidity resolution, and adverse events between laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB) and laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) in bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in excess weight loss or T2DM resolution between LRYGB and LSG, but LSG had fewer postoperative complications and reoperations. LRYGB showed superiority in dyslipidemia, hypertension, and GERD remission.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients (N = 1,328 participants).
study_duration: Mid- and long-term (specific duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence, mechanisms, risk factors, and outcomes of chronic abdominal pain and persistent opioid use following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that chronic abdominal pain affects 3-61% of patients post-surgery, while 4-14% develop persistent opioid use, which is linked to lower weight loss and reduced metabolic benefits. Physiological and pharmacokinetic changes may contribute to these outcomes, but risk factors and clinical impacts remain understudied.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery, particularly those with lower socioeconomic status.
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from 1-7 years post-surgery.
interactions: Alterations in opioid absorption and distribution post-surgery were noted, but specific interactions were not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare long-term weight loss and metabolic parameter resolution among different bariatric surgery techniques (RYGB, LSG, LAGB) and assess the impact of baseline clinical characteristics.
results_summary: RYGB resulted in the highest weight loss and metabolic syndrome resolution over 4 years, followed by LSG and LAGB. Women and younger patients had greater weight loss, while those with T2DM, hypertension, or metabolic syndrome showed less weight loss.
population_specificity: 1,837 morbidly obese patients (85% female, mean age 42.5 ± 10.6 years, mean BMI 44.0 ± 5.8).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize health economic evidence on bariatric surgery from 1995 to 2018, evaluating cost savings and quality of reporting.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was found to be cost-saving over a lifetime compared to no/conventional treatment, with medication cost savings being dominant. The study noted improvements in reporting quality and inclusion of complications/reoperations in recent evaluations.
population_specificity: Individuals with severe and resistant obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare weight loss, metabolic syndrome outcomes, complications, and long-term nutritional outcomes between Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) and one-anastomosis gastric bypass (OAGB).
results_summary: OAGB was associated with greater weight loss and better resolution of co-morbid conditions (e.g., type 2 diabetes, hypertension) compared to RYGB, but also led to more nutritional deficiencies and complications. Both procedures showed high resolution rates for sleep apnea, with OAGB slightly outperforming RYGB.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery at a high-volume, private-practice center in India in 2012, with eligibility for 5-year follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of weight loss induced by bariatric surgery on DNA methylation in adults with obesity, focusing on metabolic and inflammatory genes.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery led to significant changes in DNA methylation at specific loci, particularly PDK4 in skeletal muscle and blood, though effects on IL6 methylation were inconsistent. These changes were associated with improved metabolic and inflammatory profiles post-surgery.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the etiologies of iron deficiency anemia (IDA), including bariatric surgery, and discuss treatment options such as IV iron.
results_summary: The abstract mentions bariatric surgery as one of the causes of IDA but does not provide specific findings about its effects. It highlights the shift toward IV iron for treating IDA due to its effectiveness and improved safety profile.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of IDA etiologies, including bariatric surgery patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current understanding of metabolic syndrome (MetS) in children and adolescents, including therapeutic options like bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract states that bariatric surgery is not recommended for the majority of affected youngsters, implying limited efficacy or suitability for this population. No specific outcomes or effects of bariatric surgery are detailed.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with obesity and metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how bariatric surgery affects feeding behaviors and the brain's reward system, particularly focusing on maladaptive behaviors and potential substance abuse post-surgery.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery alters GI tract physiology, affecting feeding peptides and nutrient-sensing mechanisms, which in turn influence the brain's reward system. Some patients experience reduced appetite for palatable food, while others develop maladaptive behaviors or substance abuse.
population_specificity: Clinical population undergoing bariatric surgery

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the best strategies for diabetes management in patients undergoing bariatric surgery, focusing on glycemic control and minimizing adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery can lead to diabetes remission or reduced medication use, but adverse events like diabetic ketoacidosis were reported with certain glucose-lowering therapies. Clinicians are advised to favor weight-neutral or weight-loss promoting therapies post-surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with type 1 or type 2 diabetes undergoing bariatric surgery.
interactions: Interactions noted with SGLT2 inhibitors, insulin, and other glucose-lowering therapies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare diabetic kidney disease (DKD) rates over 5 years in severely obese adolescents with type 2 diabetes (T2D) undergoing medical treatment versus metabolic bariatric surgery (MBS).
results_summary: The study found that medical treatment of obese youth with T2D was associated with higher odds of DKD over 5 years compared to MBS, suggesting MBS may be more effective in reducing DKD risk.
population_specificity: Severely obese adolescents with type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy on remission of type 2 diabetes and β-cell function in patients with obesity and type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Gastric bypass was superior to sleeve gastrectomy for diabetes remission at 1 year, with no significant difference in β-cell function improvement between the two procedures. Both procedures had similar rates of early complications and late side-effects, with no deaths reported.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥18 years with type 2 diabetes and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how gastrointestinal hormone levels change after bariatric surgery and whether these changes predict future weight loss.
results_summary: Postprandial levels of oxyntomodulin and glicentin increased robustly three months after VSG or RYGB (but not AGB) and were associated with weight loss and satiety. These hormone changes may mediate future weight loss through satiety regulation.
population_specificity: 14 subjects in Pilot study 1 (9 AGB, 5 RYGB) and 28 subjects in the main study (17 VSG, 11 RYGB).
study_duration: Follow-up at three, six, and twelve months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of metabolic and bariatric surgery, specifically Roux-en-Y gastric bypass and vertical sleeve gastrectomy, for pediatric patients with severe obesity.
results_summary: The study found that these procedures result in sustained short-, mid-, and long-term weight loss and resolution of obesity-related comorbid diseases, with substantial evidence supporting their safety and effectiveness for children and adolescents.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (children and adolescents) with severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current obesity treatments, focusing on recent developments in polymeric carriers for enhanced antiobesity drug delivery, while noting the limitations of conventional options like bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that conventional treatments like bariatric surgery remain ineffective and carry risks of adverse effects, highlighting the need for more effective and specific therapies. Emerging drug delivery systems using polymeric materials show promise for improving therapeutic efficacy and specificity.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obesity and metabolic syndrome population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether bariatric surgery is associated with reduced risk of skin cancer, including melanoma, in individuals with obesity.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery was associated with a significantly reduced risk of melanoma (adjusted subhazard ratio, 0.43) and skin cancer in general (adjusted subhazard ratio, 0.59), with a median follow-up of 18.1 years. The risk reduction was not linked to baseline metabolic or lifestyle factors.
population_specificity: 4047 participants (mean age 47.9 years, 70.8% female) with obesity in Sweden, including 2007 who underwent bariatric surgery and 2040 matched controls receiving conventional obesity treatment.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical interventions: gastric bypass, banding, or vertical banded gastroplasty).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of bariatric surgery in short- and long-term resolution of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), recurrence, and compliance with T2DM medication post-surgery.
results_summary: Six out of seven randomized control trials showed significant advantages in glycemic control and secondary endpoints like weight loss, lipid levels, and blood pressure for surgical patients. However, the role of lifestyle modifications and T2DM medication adherence post-surgery remains understudied.
population_specificity: Patients meeting criteria for severe obesity, specifically those with T2DM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and accessibility of metabolic and bariatric surgery for youth with severe obesity.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is a safe and effective treatment for youth with severe obesity, though access remains limited, particularly for underserved populations. Lifestyle modifications showed limited success for severe obesity, while surgery demonstrated significant and durable weight loss.
population_specificity: Adolescents with severe obesity, particularly underserved populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of non-invasive variables for monitoring an open-lung approach (OLA) strategy in bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of bariatric surgery, only mentioning that twelve morbidly obese patients received baseline protective ventilation.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery, particularly sleeve gastrectomy, in managing obesity in liver transplant candidates and its impact on safety and efficacy.
results_summary: The study suggests that sleeve gastrectomy offers a good balance between safety and efficacy in liver transplant patients, though long-term outcomes remain controversial and scarce. Morbid obesity may adversely affect patient and graft survival, especially in NAFLD cases.
population_specificity: Liver transplant candidates with obesity, particularly those with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of recently developed anti-obesity medications as an innovative approach for weight loss maintenance or disease remission following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study highlights that advances in weight loss pharmacotherapy offer clinically significant weight loss potential, challenging outdated comparisons between medications and surgery. It suggests renewed enthusiasm for investigating multimodal care approaches.
population_specificity: Patients who would benefit from further weight loss or weight loss maintenance following bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the economic impact of shifting potentially avoidable emergency department (ED) visits after bariatric surgery to lower-acuity centers.
results_summary: The study found that 8.4% of bariatric surgery patients visited the ED postoperatively, with 50% resulting in readmission. Triaging avoidable ED visits to urgent care centers could save $4,238 per patient, totaling $1.6 million in savings for the cohort.
population_specificity: 36,071 patients who underwent bariatric surgery between 2011 and 2017 in a statewide quality improvement collaborative.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the outcomes of bariatric surgery in children and adolescents with severe obesity, particularly focusing on those with cognitive impairments and/or developmental delays.
results_summary: Most studies reported no peri-operative complications (69%) and improved health outcomes (79%), with variable weight-loss results (29.2-86.2% excess weight loss). No significant differences were found between youth with and without cognitive impairment and/or developmental delay in two studies.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with severe obesity, including those with cognitive impairments and/or developmental delays.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the current and potential clinical applications of calcium citrate, particularly in bariatric patients and those with osteoporosis.
results_summary: The abstract suggests calcium citrate may be beneficial for bariatric patients and those with osteoporosis, though evidence on efficacy and long-term safety is limited. Citrate salts also show potential in inhibiting kidney stone formation.
population_specificity: Bariatric patients, individuals with osteoporosis, achloridria, chronic hypoparathyroidism, and hypocitraturic subjects at risk of nephrolithiasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of magnetic sphincter augmentation (MSA) in treating GERD following gastric/bariatric surgery.
results_summary: MSA significantly improved GERD-HRQL scores post-implant compared to baseline, demonstrating feasibility in patients with refractory GERD after bariatric surgery. However, the study noted the need for further prospective and comparative studies to validate these findings.
population_specificity: Patients with persistent or de novo GERD after gastric/bariatric surgery (primarily sleeve gastrectomy or Roux-en-Y gastric bypass).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of four bariatric surgery techniques (AGB, SG, RYGB, BPD) in terms of complications, weight loss, and resolution of comorbidities like type 2 diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and sleep apnea.
results_summary: The study found that BPD had the highest weight loss (77.90% EWL) and comorbidity resolution but also the highest mortality (2.52%) and bleeding rates (2.09%). AGB had the lowest morbidity and mortality but the poorest weight loss (48.35% EWL) and diabetes resolution (46.80%). RYGB and SG showed intermediate results, with RYGB performing similarly to BPD in weight loss but with lower risks.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: Follow-up data reported at five years post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of bariatric procedures, particularly laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy, in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and discuss potential complications and management strategies.
results_summary: The study suggests that bariatric procedures are safe and effective for weight loss in IBD patients but highlights numerous post-surgical complications that can worsen IBD outcomes, leading to hospitalizations and poor quality of life. It calls for greater awareness of underlying disease processes and comorbidities in this population.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) undergoing bariatric procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the impact of weight loss interventions, including bariatric surgery, on pre-existing dermatologic conditions and the development of new skin changes.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results but indicates a review of dermatologic effects related to weight loss interventions, including bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obesity patients undergoing weight loss interventions)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of BiPAP in improving pulmonary function and reducing atelectasis in morbidly obese individuals during post-anesthetic recovery and the first postoperative day following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that BiPAP use during post-anesthetic recovery (PAR) helped maintain expiratory reserve volume (ERV) and reduced atelectasis prevalence (10% vs. 30% in the 1PO-G group). PAR-G also showed smaller declines in slow vital capacity (SVC) and forced vital capacity (FVC) compared to 1PO-G.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese individuals aged 25-55 years who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.
effective_dosage: BiPAP for one hour in either post-anesthetic recovery (PAR-G) or first postoperative day (1PO-G).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the role of bariatric surgery in managing metabolic comorbidities in NASH liver transplant recipients.
results_summary: The abstract mentions bariatric surgery as part of a broader approach to managing metabolic syndrome post-liver transplant, but no specific results or outcomes related to bariatric surgery are provided.
population_specificity: NASH liver transplant recipients with metabolic comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand sex-specific differences in metabolic and anthropometric responses to sleeve gastrectomy in obese patients.
results_summary: The study found that men improved more than women in 56% of parameters with significant cohort-wide responses, particularly showing stronger, faster, and more durable remission of diabetes symptoms. The difference in improvement may be linked to men's poorer baseline health.
population_specificity: 154 obese patients (47% men, 53% women) from the Bialystok Bariatric Surgery Study, age-matched.
study_duration: One year with four follow-up visits

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and long-term outcomes of laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (SG) in patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that 72% of ESRD patients and 48% of CKD patients achieved a body mass index of ≤40 and ≤35 kg/m², respectively, following SG. However, the abstract does not provide detailed safety or long-term outcome data.
population_specificity: Patients with ESRD and CKD (stages 1-4) meeting National Institutes of Health guidelines for bariatric surgery.
study_duration: Data collected from 2011 to 2018 (follow-up duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how support interventions (lifestyle, pharmacotherapy) could be combined or sequenced with metabolic and bariatric surgery (MBS) to optimize health outcomes for adolescents with severe obesity.
results_summary: The study found no existing research specifically reporting outcomes for the combination of lifestyle interventions with MBS, though individual results for either approach were noted. Future research is needed to explore how partnering support interventions with MBS can enhance health outcomes, particularly for high-risk populations.
population_specificity: Adolescents with severe obesity, with emphasis on ethnic minorities disproportionately affected by obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent literature on vitamin deficiencies post-bariatric surgery, focusing on vitamin D and gut microbiota, and evaluate potential interventions to improve outcomes.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery induces weight loss and metabolic improvements but with significant variability; some patients experience poor response or vitamin deficiencies despite supplementation, particularly vitamin D deficiency linked to bone loss. Gut microbiota, disrupted in obesity, partially restores post-surgery, but its role in vitamin deficiencies remains unclear.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery, particularly those with poor response or vitamin deficiencies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of conversion surgery in patients with type II obesity or higher who experienced weight regain or residual BMI >35kg/m² after initial bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Conversion surgery resulted in weight reduction, though less than the initial surgery, and stabilized weight over time. Comorbidity improvements were primarily observed after the first intervention, with acceptable perioperative morbidity rates.
population_specificity: Patients with type II obesity or higher who underwent initial bariatric surgery (VBG, GB, RYGB, or SG) and required conversion surgery due to weight regain or residual BMI >35kg/m².
study_duration: Median follow-up of 27.5 months after conversion surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine selenium deficiency in RYGB patients and evaluate nutritional treatment methods.
results_summary: Selenium deficiency was observed before and after RYGB, with lifelong supplementation and regular monitoring recommended post-surgery.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients who underwent Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass (RYGB).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review clinical and experimental literature to understand the mechanisms behind the efficacy of sleeve gastrectomy (SG) and adjustable gastric banding (AGB) in treating obesity and related disorders.
results_summary: The study found that SG and AGB are effective in sustained weight loss and improved glucose metabolism, likely due to mechanisms beyond caloric restriction, such as changes in gastrointestinal hormone secretion, hypothalamic and vagal control, energy expenditure, bile acid metabolism, and intestinal flora. These procedures are popular due to their efficacy, safety, and simplicity.
population_specificity: Human and animal models (not specified further).

study_goal: To evaluate the 10-year outcomes of bariatric surgery in Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) patients regarding weight reduction and comorbidity resolution.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery did not produce sustainable long-term weight loss or comorbidity resolution in PWS patients, suggesting it cannot be recommended as a standard treatment for this population.
population_specificity: Five PWS patients (two males, mean age 19.2 ± 3.0 years) with a body mass index of 47.3 ± 6.9 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop guidelines for psychological support pre- and post-bariatric surgery to minimize patient risk and maximize health outcomes.
results_summary: The study produced flexible, pragmatic guidelines for psychological support involving online resources, group workshops, and one-to-one sessions with a clinical psychologist, designed to be modified over time. The guidelines are feasible for use across all services and aim to improve patient outcomes.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery patients requiring psychological support pre- and post-surgery.
